sect1.title: CASE 27
sect1.para: The patient was a 21-year-old civil engineering student in the United States with expertise in water sanitation who had traveled to Ethiopia to work on a water project at a school in Addis Ababa. He presented with a 2-week history of nausea and vomiting that had increased in severity and frequency over the previous 3 days. He had been unable to keep anything down for the past 3 days and had occasional loose stools with cramping. He did not have a thermometer but had felt “hot” over the previous 3 days. He had not taken his malaria prophylaxis, nor had he taken any ciprofloxacin that was given to him by his physician in case he developed diarrhea. He worked at a school in an urban slum where he ate food and drank water even though the school did not have running water. He had never been tested for HIV but denied having had any sexual activity in Ethiopia.

listitem.para: 1. Given this history, what infectious diseases are part of this patient’s differential diagnosis?

sect1.para: On physical examination, the patient had a temperature of 38°C, blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse of 120 beats/minute. He appeared pale, exhausted, but alert and oriented. His examination was notable for his extremities being cool to the touch.

listitem.para: 2. Why do you think he appeared pale and exhausted and his extremities were “cool to the touch”?
3. Given the differential diagnosis developed in question 1, what is the significance of him being “alert and oriented”?

sect1.para: He had a peripheral white blood cell count of 15,000/μl with 13,500/μl neutrophils. He was not anemic. He had multiple peripheral blood smears done for malaria. All were negative. A fecal specimen was obtained for ova and parasite examination and stool culture. The stool was positive for occult blood and had white blood cells observed on methylene blue stain of the feces.

listitem.para: 4. What is the significance of the positive occult blood test, the presence of white blood cells on methylene blue stain, and the high peripheral white blood cell count?

sect1.para: Bacterial stool cultures were negative, but the parasite exam showed the organism in Fig. 27.1.

listitem.para: 5. Based on his clinical presentation and the organism seen in Fig. 27.1, what organism caused this patient’s infection?

listitem.para: 6. Describe the epidemiology of the pathogen infecting this patient, including the organism’s life cycle.
7. The patient was questioned about his HIV status. Why was this particularly relevant in this case?

8. Describe the pathogenesis of this organism, including a discussion of why many of the infections with this pathogen are asymptomatic and the process by which extraintestinal forms of this disease occur.
9. What diagnostic tests have been developed that greatly improved laboratory diagnosis of this disease?
10. How is this patient’s infection typically treated?

sect1.para: 1. The most common reason an individual consults a physician after traveling to sub-Saharan Africa is a systemic febrile illness with or without diarrhea, as seen in this case (1). As travel from North America and Europe to sub-Saharan Africa for business, educational, or social reasons becomes more frequent, understanding the potential agents with which such individuals are frequently infected is of greater importance. A patient returning from sub-Saharan Africa with a fever is assumed to have malaria until proven otherwise (2). This is particularly true for individuals who did not take malaria prophylaxis, as was the case here. Individuals who have been in Ethiopia are most likely to be infected with Plasmodium falciparum, which causes the most severe form of malaria (2). It is important to note that patients with malaria can have diarrhea, so its presence as part of the clinical presentation should not be used to exclude malaria from the differential diagnosis. In our experience, malaria-infected patients with the poorest outcomes do not take malaria prophylaxis, nor have malaria considered in the differential diagnosis at initial presentation with a febrile illness. Diarrheal diseases in travelers are common, especially among those who eat and drink in venues with questionable sanitation, increasing the likelihood of consuming fecally contaminated food or water. Many pathogens are possible, including Campylobacter, Shigella, Salmonella, enterotoxigenic and enteropathogenic Escherichia coli, and several protozoan parasites (3). Given the duration of the patient’s diarrhea, Giardia lamblia and Entamoeba histolytica increase in likelihood (4). Vibrio cholerae is endemic in Ethiopia, but it is highly unlikely because the disease typically resolves in less than a week (5).

Typhoid fever caused by Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi is a possibility given his diarrheal disease and likely exposure to contaminated food and water. Typhoid fever typically is a systemic illness, with diarrhea occurring in a minority of patients.
Hepatitis A and E should also be considered because both can cause vomiting and diarrhea, symptoms may be prolonged, and they are acquired by ingesting fecally contaminated food or water (6, 7).

Another common cause of systemic illness with fever in an individual from sub-Saharan Africa is tickborne rickettsial diseases with Rickettsia africae. R. africae typically causes a much milder disease than Rickettsia rickettsii, the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (8).

Both dengue and Neisseria meningitidis should be mentioned in the context of febrile illness in travelers returning from sub-Saharan Africa. Individuals who travel to Ethiopia, as well as many other countries in sub-Saharan Africa, are at risk for yellow fever and should be vaccinated against that virus, although this vaccination is not required for entry (9). Dengue is endemic in Ethiopia but is infrequent in travelers there. By contrast, it is an important agent for the febrile traveler who has recently returned from the Caribbean, Central America, South America, Southeast Asia, and the Indian subcontinent.

Finally, Ethiopia is located in the “meningitis belt” that traverses Central Africa(10). Despite the increased rate of N. meningitidis among the native population in this region, cases of N. meningitidis infection are rarely reported in travelers. Since only half of individuals who travel to that region of the world consult a physician prior to travel, it is unlikely that special precautions such as meningococcal vaccination are widely practiced in this group.

2. Given his 3-day history of vomiting, diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal discomfort coupled with a high heart rate, low-normal blood pressure, and reduced perfusion to his extremities (skin cool to the touch), he likely had significant dehydration. Starting intravenous fluids would be appropriate.

3. Given his history of not taking malaria prophylaxis, malaria is number one on his differential, especially since he has a low-grade fever. Because his mental status was good, the concern for cerebral malaria, the most severe manifestation of this infection, would be reduced. Malaria would still need to be ruled out.

4. An occult blood (or guaiac) test detects the presence of red blood cells in stools (11). The presence of red and white blood cells in stool specimens is seen in patients with dysentery (bloody diarrhea) or colitis (inflammation of the colon). Patients with colitis typically have an increased peripheral white blood count with a neutrophil predominance. Dysentery and colitis can have both infectious and noninfectious causes.

5. A patient with a clinical presentation of colitis and with trophozoites in stool consistent with E. histolytica has amebic enterocolitis. E. histolytica is a common etiologic agent of colitis in travelers to sub-Saharan Africa. There are four different species of Entamoeba that are morphologically similar: E. histolytica, E. dispar, E. moshkovskii, and E. bangladeshi (12). However, the finding of phagocytized red blood cells in the amoeba (pointed to by white arrows in Fig. 27.1) indicates E. histolytica. E. histolytica readily ingests red blood cells, while E. dispar only infrequently does and E. moshkovskii and E. bangladeshi rarely do. Other parasites that cause diarrheal disease in travelers returning from low-income countries include Cryptosporidium parvum, G. lamblia, and Cyclospora cayetanensis (4). The clinical presentation of these parasitic infections is significantly different from that seen with E. histolytica. These patients tend to have malabsorptive diarrhea, with watery, foul-smelling stools. Neither red nor white blood cells are seen in the stools of patients infected with these parasites.

6. E. histolytica infects only humans. Since it is primarily a colonic pathogen, it is passed from human to human primarily via ingesting food or water contaminated by human feces. This contamination typically occurs in environments with poor sanitation. This disease is particularly prevalent among low-income populations in sub-Saharan Africa, Central and South America, India, Asia, and the Pacific Islands (13). Children under 5 are particularly at risk for developing this infection in these areas, with malnutrition being an important risk factor for infection, morbidity, and mortality (13). It is estimated that annually 50 million cases occur globally, resulting in 40,000 to 100,000 deaths, primarily in children less than 5 years of age (13).

The life cycle of this protozoan (Fig. 27.2) is important in understanding its efficient spread. This parasite has two stages: the infective form, which is the cyst, and the pathogenic form, the trophozoite. The infection is initiated when a cyst in contaminated food or water is ingested. The cyst has a chitin-rich cell wall that allows it to survive passage through the low pH of the stomach (13). It excysts in the small intestine and releases trophozoites, which initiate infection by binding to mucins in the colon. Subsequently in the parasite’s life cycle, trophozoites encyst in the lumen of the colon to form cysts, which are excreted in feces. Those cysts are able to survive in the environment and are resistant to disinfectants such as chlorides. In environments with poor sanitation and hygiene, ingestion of food and water contaminated by these cysts can begin the infection cycle again (14).

sect1.para: 7. In the industrialized world, an important mode of E. histolytica transmission is oral-anal contact (13). This mode of transmission is typically seen in men who have sex with men (MSM). This is the population that is most likely to be infected with HIV. In MSM who are infected with E. histolytica and who do not know their HIV status, an HIV test is appropriate (15).

8. Between 80 and 90% of E. histolytica infections are asymptomatic (13). The events that result in clinical disease are multifactorial. The interplay of the pathogen, especially expression of virulence genes, and the host’s microbiota and immune system all play likely roles in intestinal and extraintestinal disease.

The initial steps in infection are reasonably well understood(13). The host ingests E. histolytica cysts. The cysts resist stomach acid, allowing them to survive passage through this organ. The cysts excyst in the small intestine, releasing trophozoites. The trophozoites have Gal/GalNAc lectins on their surface, which allows them to bind to the mucin layer overlaying the colonic epithelium, leading to amebic colitis, as was observed in this patient. In most infected individuals, the infection stops at the mucin layer due to the interplay of three factors (14). One, the particular genotype of the parasite may not express the genes necessary for the breakdown of the mucin layer. Second, certain organisms may need to be present in the microbiota to supply nutrients or enhance inflammation during the infectious process. The infectious process may not progress or be as clinically severe if they are absent. Third, individuals with prior infection may produce secretory immunoglobin A against the Gal/GalNAc lectin or have other innate immune factors such as complement that protect against infection at the intestinal epithelium surface.

The initial step in developing clinical infection is the parasite’s degradation of the mucus layer(16). Parasite genotypes that can produce glycosidases and cysteine proteases that degrade the mucin layer allow the parasite to bind to the intestinal epithelium. There, the parasite uses a newly discovered pathogenic mechanism called “trogocytosis” (17). Trogocytosis requires direct contact between the E. histolytica trophozoite and the intestinal cell. Unlike phagocytosis, where entire cells are ingested, in trogocytosis the pathogens “nibble” on intestinal cells, which ultimately results in cell death by apoptosis (16). During this process, the parasite incorporates human cell membrane proteins onto its surface using molecular mimicry to evade the host’s immune response. Paradoxically, E. histolytica can also phagocytize host cells, but data suggest they only ingest dead cells. Trogocytosis is also an important pathogenic mechanism used by Naegleria fowleri to destroy neuronal tissue during meningoencephalitis.
The trophozoites produce prostaglandins that mediate diarrhea by stimulating host cyclic AMP production, which leads to blockage of Na+ uptake and Cl– and H2O secretion, resulting in diarrhea.

The combination of contact-mediated intestinal cell killing, secretion of parasite-derived macrophage inhibitory factor promoting intestinal mucosal inflammation, coupled with the host inflammatory response stimulated by the release of interleukin-8 by infected intestinal epithelial cells, leads to bloody diarrhea and colitis characteristic of E. histolytica disease.

The damage caused by the parasite and host’s inflammatory response disrupts tight junctures between the intestinal epithelial cells and the extracellular cell matrix, allowing dissemination of the parasite into the bloodstream(16). The parasite is trapped in the liver, where it can form an abscess. Animal studies of amebic liver abscess formation demonstrate that testosterone levels determine susceptibility to abscess formation, with testosterone-treated mice having larger abscesses, higher parasitic load, and poorer outcomes compared to control mice (18). A similar pattern in seen in humans, where abscesses are 10 times more likely in men. The impact testosterone has on abscess formation may explain why men have such higher rates of E. histolytica liver abscesses.

9. In this patient, microscopic stool examination was used to diagnose E. histolytica. In much of the world, especially low-income countries, this remains the diagnostic method of choice because of its low cost and the widespread availability of light microscopes (19). The problem with this methodology is it does not reliably differentiate E. histolytica from E. dispar, E. moshkovskii, and E. bangladeshi, although the presence of trophozoites with intracellular red cells in the patient’s stool makes the diagnosis of E. histolytica likely. The sensitivity of stool microscopy is considered low (19).

Three E. histolytica additional diagnostic methods available in the industrialized world are antigen detection, antibody detection, and molecular multiplex testing, also referred to as gastrointestinal panels (19, 20). Antigen testing can detect E. histolytica in stools and aspirates from liver abscesses. There is great variability in the sensitivity of this test when stool specimens are tested (19). This variability may be due in part to the reference method used as a comparator. These tests are more reliable with liver aspirates than stool specimens, although the number of specimens used to evaluate this specimen type is limited. This testing is not widely available (19).
Antibody testing is used to detect E. histolytica as the cause of liver abscesses (19). Again, sensitivity is variable, but it appears more sensitive than antigen testing.

Gastrointestinal panels that rely on multiplex nucleic acid amplification are widely available in the industrialized world and are replacing bacterial culture, viral antigen tests, and parasitic microscopic examination to determine the etiology of infectious diarrhea disease(20). The bacterial, viral, and protozoan parasitic agents detected depend on the specific panel used. The current literature suggests that molecular multiplex panels appear to be highly sensitive for detecting E. histolytica in stools (19).

In the United States, gastrointestinal panels are widely used detection methods for E. histolytica. In one study evaluating more than 9,000 patients, only two tested positive, suggesting that this pathogen is rarely encountered as a cause of diarrhea in the United States (20).
As far as testing for this pathogen in stools, microscopic examination and molecular detection are the most likely available methods.
10. Because the patient was vomiting and dehydrated, he needed to receive intravenous fluids emergently. E. histolytica enterocolitis is treated with either oral metronidazole or tinidazole.

Given this patient’s confirmed diagnosis via stool parasite exam, he was prescribed metronidazole, 500 mg three times a day for 10 days. After the completion of a sufficient course of intravenous fluids, the patient was discharged home with instructions to continue the oral metronidazole for the remainder of the treatment course.

listitem.para: E. histolytica is a protozoan parasite that can cause amebic dysentery and colitis. In a small number of individuals, the parasite may disseminate from the gastrointestinal tract to the liver, resulting in a liver abscess. Ninety percent of E. histolytica infections are asymptomatic.

This protozoan has a fairly simple life cycle. The infectious form is a cyst with a chitin-rich cell wall that allows this stage to survive in hostile environments such as in the low pH of the human stomach. The pathogenic stage of the parasite is the trophozoite, which uses a surface lectin to bind to intestinal mucins in the colon.

E. histolytica is a human pathogen generally spread by ingesting food or water contaminated by feces from infected individuals in areas with poor sanitation/hygiene. It is endemic in low-income countries where clean water supplies are limited.

The pathogenicity of E. histolytica is based on the interplay of the expression of virulence genes; microbiota constituents that play a role by providing nutrients for the pathogen and enhancing inflammation; and the host’s inflammatory response, which contributes to the tissue damage seen in the disease process.

A novel pathogenic mechanism called trogocytosis was first observed in E. histolytica. Direct contact between the pathogen and the host gastrointestinal epithelial cells meditated by the Gal/GalNAc lectin on the surface of the pathogen allows the pathogen to “nibble” on the surface of the host cells, resulting in apoptosis. This process is central to the colitis and liver abscesses that occur in patients infected with E. histolytica.
E. histolytica liver abscesses are 10 times more likely to occur in men. Testosterone’s effect on the immune response to this pathogen may explain this difference.

Molecular detection of E. histolytica is a more sensitive diagnostic method than microscopic detection for amebic colitis. Detection of E. histolytica antibodies is the recommended method for diagnosing liver abscesses due to this pathogen.
